byline.original: By MUJIB MASHAL, ZAHRA NADER and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

abstract: Bodies of 80 protesters killed in Kabul, Afghanistan, in bombing claimed by Islamic State are buried quickly in closely packed graves, leading to blur of sorrow for mourners; carnage has drawn attention to plight of Hazara ethnic minority, who formed most of protest group and have long been treated as second-class citizens.
lead_paragraph: Ethnic Hazaras gathered on a hilltop cemetery near Kabul to mourn nearly two dozen relatives and friends, among at least 80 killed in a bombing claimed by the Islamic State a day earlier.

headline.main: Kabul Bombing Adds New Layers of Agony for Afghanistan’s Hazaras
headline.print_headline: Row After Row, Burying a New Ledger of Civilian Victims in Afghanistan
